Sunrise Module¶

sunrise.day_number(hour_number)¶

Returns the day_number given a particular hour_number.

hour_numberfloat

The number of hours since Jan first of a given year

day_numberint

The hour number

Midnight on day 366 of a leap year

>>> hour_number = 8784
>>> day_number(hour_number)
    366
sunrise.declination(hour, leap_year=False)¶

This function calculates the declination angle of the sun.

hourinteger, float

The hour of the day. Could be a decimal value.

leap_yearboolean

Indicates if the year is a leap year. Default is False.

deltafloat

The declination at the given hour

The declination six minutes into January third of a leap year can be calculated as follows. It is important to remember that for a leap year you must put the True Boolean as the second parameter. If you want a non-leap year you can either put only one argument or use the False Boolean.

>>> hour = hour_number(3,0.1)
>>> declination(hour, True)
    -22.81293175279647
sunrise.equation_of_time(hour, leap_year=False)¶

This function calculates the equation of time. The equation of time gives the difference between the solar time and wall clock time, effectively correcting for the eccentricity of Earth’s orbit.

hourfloat

The number of hours since midnight, January first.

etfloat

The time in minutes

Equation of time at six minutes on January 3rd of a leap year It is important to remember that for a leap year you must put the True Boolean as the second parameter. If you want a non-leap year you can either put only one argument or use the False Boolean.

>>> hour = hour_number(3,0.1)
>>> equation_of_time(hour, True)
    -4.684279708368122
sunrise.frac_year(hour, leap_year=False)¶

This function calculates the fraction of the year.

hourinteger, float

The hour of the day. Could be a decimal value.

leap_yearboolean

Indicates if the year is a leap year. Default is False.

Bfloat

The fraction of the year

Six minutes into the third day of a leap year. It is important to remember that for a leap year you must put the True Boolean as the second parameter. If you want a non-leap year you can either put only one argument or use the False Boolean.

>>> hour = hour_number(3, 0.1)
>>> frac_year(hour, True)
    -76.7172131147541
sunrise.generate_elevation_series(hour_range, lat=40.081798, lon=- 88.244027, utc=- 6, timestamps=False)¶

Creates a time series of elevation angles for a given set of hours or Pandas timestamps.

hour_rangenumpy array or pandas series of Timestamps

The time period of desired solar elevation angles. Default is a list of hours, a pandas series of timestamps can also be accepted if the timesteps argument is set to True.

latfloat

The latitude of the location of interest

lonfloat

The longitude of the location of interest

utcinteger

The time shift from the Coordinated Universal Time. Western longitudes have UTC < 0. Eastern longitudes have UTC > 0.

timestampsboolean

Specifies the type of the hour_range. Default is False (hour_range is array of float or int). True if hour_range is a pandas series of Timestamps.

elevation_angleslist

The list of elevation angles corresponding to each hour or timestamp. Units in degrees.

Find the elevation angles for Solar Farm 1.0 in Urbana, IL on the first day at time zero and six minutes later.

>>> hour_range = [0, 0.1]
>>> lat = 40.081798
>>> lon = -88.244027
>>> utc = -6
>>> generate_elevation_series(hour_range, lat, lon, utc)
    [-72.97564456089731, -72.86924538817553]
sunrise.hour_angle(lst)¶

This function calculates the hour angle of the sun. The hour angle is the number of degrees the sun has moved across the sky.

lstfloat

The local solar time

hafloat

The hour angle in minutes

For six minutes into the third day of January of a leap year at Solar Farm 1.0 in Urbana IL, calculate the hour angle as follows. Remember to use the True and False Booleans accordingly, where True corresponds to a leap year.

>>> hour = hour_number(3,0.1)
>>> et = equation_of_time(hour, True)
>>> lon = -88.244027
>>> utc = -6
>>> lstm = local_meridian(utc)
>>> tc = time_correction(lstm, et, lon)
>>> local_time = local_time(0.1)
>>> lst = local_solar_time(local_time, tc)
>>> hour_angle(lst)
    -177.55855552584526
sunrise.hour_number(N, time)¶

Takes the day number and time (in hours) and converts to hour number.

Ninteger

The day number

timefloat

The time in hours (24-hour clock)

hourfloat

The hour number

Take the example of six minutes into January first

>>> N = 1
>>> time = 0.1
>>> hour_number(N, time)
    24.1
sunrise.local_meridian(utc=- 6)¶

This function calculates the local standard time meridian, LSTM. The LSTM is a reference meridian for given time zones. LSTM is calculated according to the equation:

LSTM = 360/24*UTC

UTC < 0 gives the answer in degrees West. UTC > 0 gives the answer in degrees East.

utcinteger

UTC is the “coordinated universal time.” This parameter gives the UTC offset for a particular timezone. E.g. Chicago time is UTC-5, so we take utc = 5.

lstmfloat

The LSTM in degrees

Calculating the Local Meridian for Urbana, IL

>>> utc = -6
>>> local_meridian(utc)
    -90
sunrise.local_solar_time(local_time, tc)¶

Corrects the local time to give the local solar time.

local_timefloat

The local time in hours

tc : the time correction factor

lstfloat

The local solar time in hours.

For six minutes into the third day of January of a leap year at Solar Farm 1.0 in Urbana IL, calculate the local solar time as follows. Remember to use the True and False Booleans accordingly, where True corresponds to a leap year.

>>> hour = hour_number(3,0.1)
>>> et = equation_of_time(hour, True)
>>> lon = -88.244027
>>> utc = -6
>>> lstm = local_meridian(utc)
>>> tc = time_correction(lstm, et, lon)
>>> local_time = local_time(0.1)
>>> local_solar_time(local_time, tc)
    0.16276296494364917
sunrise.local_time(hour_number)¶

Takes the hour number, and converts to local time.

hour_numberfloat

The number of hours since Jan first of a given year

timefloat

The number of hours since 12 AM on any given day

Midnight on the third day of a year.

>>> N_days = 3
>>> time = 24
>>> hour_number = hour_number(3, 24)
>>> local_time(hour_number)
    0
sunrise.solar_elevation(ha, delta, lat=40.081798)¶

Calculate the solar elevation for a given hour angle, latitude, and declination.

hafloat

The hour angle

deltafloat

The declination angle

latfloat

The latitude at the location of interest.

alphafloat

The elevation angle

For six minutes into the third day of January of a leap year at Solar Farm 1.0 in Urbana IL, calculate the solar elevation as follows. Remember to use the True and False Booleans accordingly, where True corresponds to a leap year.

>>> hour = hour_number(3,0.1)
>>> et = equation_of_time(hour, True)
>>> lon = -88.244027
>>> utc = -6
>>> lstm = local_meridian(utc)
>>> tc = time_correction(lstm, et, lon)
>>> local_time = local_time(0.1)
>>> lst = local_solar_time(local_time, tc)
>>> ha = hour_angle(lst)
>>> delta = declination(hour, True)
>>> lat = 40.081798
>>> solar_elevation(ha, delta, lat)
    -72.64124833502152
sunrise.time_correction(lstm, et, lon=- 88.244027)¶

The time correction factor adjusts for differences in Local Solar Time (LST) and the location of interest, at a given longitude. There is a factor of 4 due to the speed of Earth’s rotation.

lstmfloat

The local standard time meridian.

etfloat

The equation of time.

lonfloat

The longitude of the location of interest.

tcfloat

Time correction factor in minutes.

To calculate the time correction at Solar Farm 1.0 in Champaign Illinois, define the longitude, hour, and utm. Then use the local_meridian and equation_of_time functions to calculate et and lstm. Six minutes into a non-leap year at Solar Farm 1.0 the time_correction calculation looks like

>>> hour = 0.1
>>> lon = -88.244027
>>> utc = -6
>>> lstm = local_meridian(utc)
>>> et = equation_of_time(hour, False)
>>> time_correction(lstm, et, lon)
3.7657778966189506
sunrise.timestamp_to_hour(timestamp)¶

This function returns the hour number of a particular timestamp.

timestamppandas Timestamp

The time stamp of interest, must be in 24-hour.

hourfloat

The number of hours since 12 AM on January first.

Take the example of six minutes into January in 2017.

>>> import pandas as pd
>>> timestamp = pd.Timestamp('2017-01-01T0006')
>>> print(timestamp)
    2017-01-01 00:06:00
>>> timestamp_to_hour(timestamp)
    24.1
